Comment: I'm actually OK with the paid leave, providing that the investigation is honest and timely. Speaking broadly, it's a safety mechanism that allows time to investigate allegations while at the same time removing the subject from a position where they can do further harm if the allegations turn out to be correct, and minimizing the harm to the subject if the allegations turn out to be incorrect.

In this particular case it looks pretty clear cut -- but at the same time, I don't think I would want an organization to immediately fire someone based solely on a newspaper article and photograph. Putting them on leave while the district spends a few days looking more closely at the incident seems reasonable to me in terms of the greater good.

Comment: There is a way to take advantage of the CDIC if an investor believes that Home Capital will go bankrupt in the near-to-medium term.  

Purchase a 5-year GIC from Home Capital for 3.1%, keeping the amount under the $100,000 threshold for your own protection.  If the firm goes bankrupt in, say, 2 years, the CDIC will pay you interest for 2 years at 3.1%...higher than a 2 year GIC rate, along with the original principal.

Of course, nobody knows when (or if) Home Capital would go bankrupt and, even if they were near bankruptcy, OSFI and the CDIC would most likely broker a sale of Home Capital to another financial institution, thus keeping your GIC safe.

Comment: See my reply below to Steve. I think it is also important to recognize two additional elements of this whole affair:

(1) The DNC servers were not handed over to the FBI. Instead the DNC relied on a private cyber forensic & security company (with a good reputation but also a long record of Russian cyber attribution). Cyber forensic attribution is notoriously difficult; numerous articles have critised the original (Crowdstrike) report and the subsequent intelligence community (IC) assessment.  Including left-wing sites like the Intercept. 

(2) The IC did not assess Russian "influenced the election outcome"; merely that they meddled and tried to influence. 

Again, this stuff frequently gets conflated in the media. 

I am not so interested in defending Trump; as exposing just how critical we need to be of the media, especially in the current social media environment. They are doing a good job of making the Trump "fake news" slur stick...

This fatality could have been avoided.

When I camp in Mother Nature's domain, one of the basics outside of 1st aide and shelter for us humans, is a couple of very long lengths of nylon rope.  I'll tie it to a heavy rock or stick and toss it up over a sturdy branch so that it is at LEAST 15-20 feet up off the ground and not easily climbed to or shimmied down if a bear decides to try and grab from the limb if it climbs up.

Your food TRASH needs to be afixed from above too.

Never keep food in your tent, EVER.

Try to plan your meals so that perhaps all you are doing is adding water and cooking or eating from the bag it comes in if dehydrated.  One can order dehydrated food online, buy at REI, etc.  No water weight to have to hoist up off the ground.  Use your NOGGINS.

Comment: Most people resist change and when competition is involved change is inevitable.  If you want a slower, more traditional race then run the Yukon quest. Mitch and Dallas have changed the way the race is run and have proved that they can win with teams that haven't been pushed to the edge but that would continue down the trail if the race was even longer.  It isn't just resting dogs in the sled, they also train year round! Most mushers are used to taking the summers off and it takes a lot of effort to figure out how to exercise dogs in the summer.  Also mushers like nick petit, who wasn't resting dogs in his sled, almost caught them so the resting dogs isn't the only way to win. Iditarod isn't going to slow down and if you want a camping trip where you build fires in the wilderness and cook the beaver you just killed to feed your dogs then start a new race.  There are plenty of other races to run or you can run Iditarod knowing that your not going to be in the top 30.

Comment: In regards to the question of non-unanimous jury verdicts, Perlow claims that, "a criminal defendant can benefit from having 10 of 12 people voting to acquit".  If unanimous verdicts were required, a defendant would benefit from a hung jury with 10 of 12 voting to acquit, because if the prosecutor polled the jury and found that 10 people voted to acquit, he would be unlikely to re-file charges and go to trial again.
If a jury votes 10 of 12 to convict a person, it means that the prosecutor has failed to prove his case "beyond a reasonable doubt", because the two people voting to acquit had enough reasonable doubt to acquit. Since a person is presumed innocent until proven guilty (beyond a reasonable doubt), a person in this case should still be considered to be innocent. In that case the prosecutor has the option of re-filing the charges and trying the case again.

Comment: The bottom line is not that that rail has already run out of money and on the verge of running out of time, but both the city and state are technically insolvent and are also running out of time. Comment: Hi Jack-- I'm not a lawyer, either! Any information that I've posted above was my opinion after other professional training for teachers and reading the following sources:

Measuring Fair Use: The Four Factors (http://fairuse.stanford.edu/overview/fair-use/four-factors/)

Copyright Infringement: How are Damages Determined? (http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/copyright-infringement-how-damages-determined.html)

To your first question, I don't think there would be a way to prove actual damages or loss of profit, so if a case were pressed, it's likely that statutory damages would be pursued. The cost may have been $750 per instance, dropped to $200 per judge discretion if the infringer did not believe they were violating copyright.

The most likely consequence would just be the company sending a cease and desist letter.

Comment: JB is right; climate change can have some pretty dramatic effects.  Since the pass of the Last Glacial Maximum, sea levels have risen over 100 m, drowning immense areas of low-lying tropical rainforests in SE Asia, cutting off Britain from the rest of Europe, submerging island habitats beneath the waves.  In the meantime, changes in rainfall and snowfall transformed huge swathes of the American West from a fruitful terrane of lakes and meadows and streams to a semi-arid wasteland - leading to the demise of hundreds of species of iconic mammals, birds, and fish.  (Haven't seen a mastodon or a giant ground sloth lately, have you??)  Similarly, North Africa went from a verdant land of rivers, woods, and grasslands, populated by people and magnificent African game, to the world's largest desert.

*And the Democratic Party didn't do a damn thing to stop it!*

It's true!  :)   (Man, that sure determines how *I'm* going to vote!)

/{sarcoff}

Comment: There's transient debt based spending and permanent debt based spending.

The former follows from Keynesian theory, and the Conservative government followed the theory quite dogmatically - borrowing during severe downturns to prime the economic pump, then eliminating the deficit and repaying the debt during economic boom times.

The current government pitches the need to borrow during relatively good times, then borrows even more as the economy's performance peaks. It follows a well-travelled road towards bankruptcy, exemplified most recently in this country by the current PM's father at the federal level, and his close political colleague Kathleen Wynne at the provincial level.

Comment: The 14th Amendment already provides for "equal protection of the laws", which figures prominently in a wide variety of landmark cases, including Brown v. Board of Education (racial discrimination), Roe v. Wade (reproductive rights),  Bush v. Gore (election recounts), Reed v. Reed (gender discrimination),  and University of California v. Bakke (racial quotas in education)."  https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/amendmentxiv

However, when any law is passed that cites ONLY certain people and provides ONLY those certain people with certain rights and privileges, then ONLY those certain people are in that "protected class" and all others do NOT therefore still have  "equal protection of the laws", because the law does NOT ALSO grant those same rights and privileges to EVERYONE. https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/equal_protection

Comment: According to Alceste, this case is about:

"* TWU rules allowed married heterosexual students to have sex together.

* TWU rules do NOT allow same-sex married students to have sex together."

As you can see, TWU's policy has a discriminatory feature. It doesn't treat same-sex married students the same as it treats heterosexual married students. As you can also see, TWU can rectify that discrimination in more than one way. The first way would be to allow same-sex married students to have sex together. However, that would be a total repudiation of TWU's principles and beliefs. The second way would be to ask all students, married or not, to refrain from having sex while attending the university. That would treat all students equally, and hence LSUC's case would immediately fall apart.

Given that TWU is a school of devout Christian believers, if forced to do so which do you think they would choose: To repudiate their beliefs, or to make a temporary sacrifice for them?

Comment: Many First Nations (Indian) people in Canada don't seem to want oil pipelines like the Trans Mountain oil pipeline through BC. Others want the government to consult.

In the 2004 Haida case, the Supreme Court of Canada said “Third parties cannot be held liable for failing to discharge the Crown’s duty to consult and accommodate. The honour of the Crown cannot be delegated, and the legal responsibility for consultation and accommodation rests with the Crown". 

But, section 48 of the Haida case says “This process does not give Aboriginal groups a veto over what can be done with land pending final proof of the claim". 

The First Nations (Indian) people in Canada can protest peacefully but they can't illegally block or veto the oil pipelines.

Comment: Since LTD begun their focus on EmX projects and proposals, they have been forced to cut 19% of their basic transit service, have lost about 10% ridership.

The medical complex at RiverBend employs about 4,000 workers, yet the complex only generates just over 100 boardings per weekday, and none on weekends.  It’s interesting to note that LTD has disguised their poor ridership by using percentages instead of actual boarding numbers.  

The West Eugene EmX won't do any better.  Eugene gets less effeicient transit, at a higher cost.

Comment: Several years ago, when using a computer with backup UPS power, the gauge
on the unit said the local utility (Chugach) was supplying 132 Volts... 

Since my 'uninterruptable power supply' with automatic voltage regulation on thoroughput was handling the irregularity with ease, I thought to call the dispatch line at Chugach; to inform them directly.

To be able to call the actual power experts, saves a lot of time and grief. I was able to
suggest that perhaps at an earlier maintenance interval, someone may have tested the system and had not set it back to the usual & customary output. I was spot-on; my suspicions confirmed.

(Not the first time I'd found an issue, or diagnosed a problem, as end-user Chugach customer.)

Most the people working there at desks have no idea what I've said, in regard to odd power effects, from a distance outside the city. They live a different life; many more outages, reasons, longer failures due to weather, trees, avalanches, etc. outside town. Such fun ;)

Comment: I'd give him a massive fail. His argument that having people on the roads is worse is nonsense. Any idiot heads to higher ground when there is flooding rather than sit there and gamble on being rescued. If you don't warn people about flooding they assume staying is OK.

Worst flooding we ever was not from a hurricanes. One spring many years ago we had 3 straight days of torrential downpours, heavier than a lot of tropical storms. Our area had 23 inches fall in 24 hours. About 20% of Tampa had a foot or more of water in the streets and we are right next to Tampa Bay which might as well be the Gulf of Mexico. What failed us was plugged sewers and it raining faster than the drainage could move the water. Good and bad for us is just North of us is a huge watershed, thousands of acres of swamps that drain into the river. The good is it mitigates heavy rains acting like a retention pond. The bad is it takes days for water to work its way out. You need to know the capacity of your system.

Comment: Your comments on the number of police involved responding to a simple call isn't too far off, but it isn't that simple.  First, you still require a minimum number of patrol members on the road, to ensure there is coverage for more serious calls.  The real problem lies in the legal system that has made it so difficult to investigate any major case, and charging someone with murder, or manslaughter for selling bad drugs is just that.  

If all the police had to do was arrest the person, charge them and walk away, it would be easy.  But case law now demands huge amounts of disclosure evidence from the police relating to every charge.  And, guess how that is done, by hand, compiling and vetting each document.   There is no computer program to do it totally.  You would be amazed to find the number of people employed in every police office dealing with just disclosure issues.  If the disclosure isn't complete, the bad guy walks.  It is more complicated that that, but that is the start.

Comment: A forester with experience in fire behaviour told me so. Apart from that, I have seen for myself how a fire spots ahead of the fire front by 10s, 100s of metres and even kilometers.  Some firebreaks will stop slow-moving, low intensity ground-level fires.  A fire in dense vegetation with a wind behind it easily jumps such obstacles.  The Knysna fires are an obvious example, the fire jumped the river and wetlands, which are wider than any firebreak.   But think about it, how do you fight a wildfire if you can hardly get through the vegetation. How do you stand next to an intense fire? Practically, you cannot.  Apart from that, firefighters need an escape route.

Comment: My Grandfather and Grandmother bought a piece of land before I was born. My family worked on clearing part of the land so they could build a cabin on it. It was made out of real rock my family gathered from the forest cast into blocks. A fortress. My grandfathers goal was to build it and retire there with my grandmother. She ended up having a stroke. He lost interest and just threw a roof on top of the unfinished building. After they both passed away, my parents & me kept going up to enjoy it. No running water, basic electricity and a wood stove my dad made. I grew up going there in the summer and even winters. I knew every stone in that area. 13 acres of pristine land on a private lake. It was time for my mother to retire, they were still paying for a mortgage. They ended up selling it over a decade ago, something I agreed to and now majorly regret. I found out just the other day that the new owner tore it down to build a rental cottage on it. Its eating me up.... Really depressing

Comment: You're still buying debt, someone needs to owe. You can't bash people going into debt if you want to be able to save money. If no one is issuing new debt, interest rates would fall even further than they currently are. The system requires balance, and the inflation rate is what the central banks rightly use as their measure of debt creation. Right now we have a lot of people saving money instead of spending it and fewer people willing to go into debt, the result is that interest rates have fallen. In this circumstance the central banks have to keep rates low to avoid the defaulting problem due to insufficient money creation.

ie: Mushers in Finland are working with the International Institute of Animal Ethics, and inquired about using the Sled Dogs documentary at a mushing conference, using it as a lever to having a keynote talk on responsible welfare and out of date standards. 

The World Sleddog Association states, “Unfortunately, in some countries it is permitted to keep dogs on chains. Nevertheless, this practice should be rejected by all sled dog organizations nationally and internationally. Sled dog organizations should engage with mushers practicing this with the aim to abolish this practice.” WSA member clubs follow this rule.

There are those of us who are working toward a humane sport. Many past, accepted cruelties and neglectful practices are no longer being swept under the rug. Mushers will need to adapt.

Comment: Regarding your comment that we are becoming a "European form of government" I would counter that we are the only modern industrialized nation in the world without some form of universal health coverage for its citizens. If you research healthcare systems and not rely on getting your info from right wing talking heads, you will find that we are a nation of many healthcare systems. There are basically 4 heathcare systems: the "single-payer" system (Medicaid, Medicare) is called the "Canadian system". Military/VA is the "British system" (socialized medicine). If you get your medical insurance through your employer (which is basically what we have here in Hawaii) that is called the "German system". No system, you don't have any insurance and one illness could ruin you financially or cause you too die, is called the "Cambodian system". I don't want to get into the nitty gritty like the "free rider" problem but IMHO after researching healthcare systems "single-payer" is the way we should go.

Comment: With regards to the specific issue of refugee claimants coming across the border between Canada and the U.S., we have an agreement with the U.S. that defines each other as "Safe" countries:

Canada has only officially designated the U.S. as a "safe" country probably because it isn't worth our while to designate any other country simply for geographic reasons.  While I'm sure some refugees come into Canada on planes from the U.K. or France or some such, the numbers are probably negligible.  Most refugees claimants come more or less direct from their home countries such as Mexico, Hungary, Romania, etc. OR they are specifically selected as refugees by Canada.

Comment: I am concerned about the way Ms. Weeks has misconstrued ABUS as an 'alternative' to mammogram. ABUS is approved by Health Canada for screening purposes, as an addition to mammography. Ms.Weeks neglected to write about why ABUS is beneficial as a supplementary screening tool. For women with dense breast tissue, tumours are sometimes hidden behind dense tissue because both  appear white on a mammogram.  40% of women over age 40- 3 million women in Canada- have dense breasts. ABUS finds small, invasive, node negative cancers. Evidence shows ABUS detects an additional 3.6 cancers per 1000 women screened after mammography (Berg, 2016). ABUS, in addition, to mammography can significantly improve cancer detection for women with dense breasts.  In fact, the Alberta health ministry covers the cost of ABUS for women with the highest level of breast density. By ignoring how ABUS is a beneficial supplementary screen for women with dense breasts, Ms. Weeks failed to provide a complete picture.

Comment: I don't disagree with the content of John Doyle's piece--found it quite illuminating--but disagree with the headline and the basic premise.  

What John Doyle describes is NOT conventional TV.  "...if networks offer their content, on-demand and online, that makes it easier for viewers to catch up with shows that got attention but were missed the first time they aired on a specific day and time slot. It took several years for this to happen..."  And, "The key here is "across all platforms" – people are far more willing to watch TV on all manner of devices right now. ... Far from being the enemy, streaming turned out to be the kick that conventional TV needed."

All of these innovations mean that conventional TV has been dead for some years.  Nobody would tolerate being told, "Nacos is on every Thursday night at 8 p.m. on such-and-such network. If you want to see it, punch up that network's closest station, on that day, at that time. Thank you."

Comment: All gains in labour productivity ultimately come from innovation.
.
Ironically, Adam Smith made precisely this observation in The Wealth of Nations in 1774.  It is still true.
.
However, Canada, with all its advantages, has a tax system and a banking system that are astonishingly biased in favour of resource extraction.
.
It may not seem to matter, until you realise that quite apart from being environmentally unsustainable, and quite apart from the unlimited generation of negative externalities,  the relentless subsidization of resource extraction is paid for by the rest of the economy.
.
It is a huge penalty.  A millstone.  A ball and chain. A deadweight. 
.
It is an enormous tax on innovation.  It is holding our economy back.
.
There is nothing wrong with an economy that includes resource extraction.
.
But for the love of God stop subsidising it at the expense of the rest of the economy.

Comment: The normalization process will happen in fits and starts.  This exactly what I would have expected.  The weakest links will break first.  The first people to get shaken out of the real estate market are those who bought(really just put down a deposit) pre-build houses out in the far burbs (Milton, Georgetown, etc...).  Those areas are now dead quiet.  The value of these future houses have already dropped by more than the deposits that were put down. They are holding out now, trying to find people to take over their contracts, but eventually they'll have to walk away. The second phase will be condo speculators.  They were never end users to begin with.  I think many were locals taking equity out of their homes to speculate. I think third will be homes in the immediate suburbs of Toronto (Mississauga,  Oakville,..).  And slowly that wave will recede to Toronto.

Comment: >And yet, they still managed to inflict a massive defeat on the technologically far superior British Army (albeit at the cost of many Zulu lives) 
Indeed - proving that military technology alone isn't enough to secure an easy victory against a skilled and determined foe, especially on their home soil. 
Mind you - they were only a *little* inferior in truth  - especially when compared to the front-loading Mausers that the Boer armies had. There's a reason the Boers lost their first two battles against the Zulus. Blood river was an exceptional outcome - not just for the how greatly the Boers were outnumbered but because better weapons wasn't the major thing that turned the tide there. Historically - such battles always had some outside influencer. The Conquistadores beat 80-thousand men with just a hundred - thanks to smallpox. Leonidas had geography on his side. And Andries Pretorius had both geography and some very lucky weather.

Comment: Taxation is a clumsy, costly (administration overhead) and unlikely to be effective. What we are seeing is naked politics.

The damage from the calories model of nutrition and soft drink propaganda, like it being okay to consume sugar if you move more, has been done. We've lost a generation and probably more with epigenetic effects. What a sugar tax might accomplish is reduce the number of people who become addicts in the future.

Comment: Doesn't mean much? It's a simple statement of fact. "That money was later reimbursed by the federal government."
 
Government prints money, but doesn't actually create wealth. Any "Federal money" is either tax revenue, which is direct wealth redistribution, or debt financing, which has to be paid off by future tax revenues (or defaulted on), which is indirect wealth redistribution. There is no such thing as a free lunch. The money comes from someone, if not from the recipient, it is transferred from someone else's nigh-literal pocket.

You assume your premise and oversimplify when you create a binary choice between subsidized healthcare and "unaffordable healthcare." Even before the ACA the number of people who actually "could not afford healthcare" (itself a gross oversimplification) was a small minority of a few millions who could have been dealt with in any number of less disruptive and costly ways if the true underlying goal of ACA's proponents wasn't eventual nationalization.

Comment: "They" give the president nothing. There is no "they."

The president nominates a chairman from among the seven sitting governors, under the Banking Act of 1935; this is subject to Senate confirmation. No different, really, than any other presidential appointment. 

That also keeps the chairman and the board of governors somewhat more insulated from the political fray. Can you imagine the chaos of monetary policy under straight-line democracy, changing willy-nilly as the political winds shift? I consider myself better informed than, say, most other schlubs on the streets, but I'll admit I'm not expert enough to know who would have the best view on the federal funds overnight benchmark rate and when is the right time to adjust it.

Comment: If you face the same standards and expectations as everyone else, and find the job overwhelming, then you don't belong in that job.  Go find a better fit elsewhere.

Passing probation should not be the end goal.  While the bar for releasing an employee is lower for those on probation, it's still quite possible to release a non-probationary employee for poor performance.   Six months of "due process", done properly, and anyone could be released.  

I have seen poor performing employees play the mental health, discrimination and harassment cards in a last ditch effort to hold their jobs.  It almost never works, unless there is disclosure well in advance of the culminating incident.  The stress of the moment may be a mitigating factor, but it is not directive on its own.  

Both experts were correct that details of your departure must be kept confidential.  As the employer, I would simply confirm start and end dates, the role performed, and that the employee resigned.  No more.

Comment: Lars Bauer wrote: "And when they've done that to us (twice, in our experience); we happily take the $500 voucher (which is a generous offer, since they are under NO obligation to do that), go to the lounge, pour a cold one, and wait for the next flight."
.
Actually Lars, depending on where you are going the carrier is probably getting off cheap by giving you a voucher.  If you don't get to your destination in less than two hours of the scheduled time the carrier owes you the cost of a one-way ticket x2 and you get to keep your original ticket.  If it's more than 2 hours the carrier owes you the one way fare to your destination x4 - and you get to keep your original ticket.  See:
http://www.kfdi.com/news/national/passangers-rights-federal-laws-allow-for-overbooking

Comment: We should be careful not to generalize too much. Each pipeline proposal has unique aspects and should be judged on those elements: public safety, potential environmental impacts (including climate change), who assumes risks vs who benefits, our long-term energy security vs increased exports, etc.

Energy East was problematic from the outset: it's the longest possible route to tidewater. That raises issues of risk as well as the obvious matter of cost to the shippers.

Another widely overlooked problem was the plan to repurpose the existing pipe, clearly TC's primary motivation. The existing pipe comprises two-thirds of EE's length and crosses four provinces. At 42" diameter it is among the largest in Canada. At 1.1 mbpd its capacity far exceeds what our eastern refineries can use, especially since the revival of Line 9.

But the real kicker in my opinion is wall thickness: the existing pipe is only 3/8" thick. This yields a diameter/thickness ("D/t") ratio of 112. [TCB]

Comment: The focus on the tuition list price in this editorial is simplistic and shows to RG editors haven't done their homework. 

UO should be *increasing* the tuition list price, and use the money to increase the discounts that it offers to good low and middle income students. We’ve done this for the lowest income students with PathwayOregon – supported with generous donations from UO Trustee Connie Ballmer. Raising tuition would allow bringing in more of these students.

Tuition increases can also fund programs to encourage quicker graduation and decrease the dropout rate – as President Schill has already started. Both these projects have the potential to cut the cost of college graduation by far more than enough to offset tuition increases. 

A 4-year degree is a very high-return investment for students and society. UO’s focus should be on increasing access to those degrees and improving their value, and tuition limits are not a sensible way to do either.

Comment: Thanks for your response :)

There is the ideal: No illegal immigration. A system that treats people who come here legally fairly. There is reality: 11 million undocumented immigrants.

You can't simply switch from reality to the ideal. For the places that have tried this (Arizona and Alabama) it resulted in very dire consequences for U.S. citizens, the economy, public safety, and the U.S. Constitution.  I'm for finding a compromise that that won't result in something ultimately hurting us and implementing policies the majority of people will regret - likely without solving the issue we want to solve. 

I think a combination of immigration reform, border security (not sure a wall is the answer, but I suppose it's a powerful symbol), continuing to deport criminals, and offering a path to citizenship or fair work visas for those already here is a reasonable compromise on all levels. People should have to make amends, but in thoughtful way that fixes it.

Comment: 8. February: Mike Flynn scandal. Reports emerge that the FBI intercepted a conversation in 2016 between future National Security Adviser Michael Flynn — then a private citizen — and Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. The intercept supposedly was  part of routine spying on the ambassador, not monitoring of the Trump campaign. The FBI transcripts reportedly show the two discussing Obama’s newly-imposed sanctions on Russia, though Flynn earlier denied discussing them. Sally Yates, whom Trump would later fire as acting Attorney General for insubordination, is involved in the investigation. In the end, Flynn resigns over having misled Vice President Mike Pence (perhaps inadvertently) about the content of the conversation.

Comment: Descriptive feedback is not new. This has been around for many years, as it has been shown to be an effective component of moving students forward, provided they make use of the feedback. For example, returning to a student a draft of an essay with suggestions (which can be delivered by peers or teacher). If the student chooses to ignore the time-consuming feedback, this will reflect their final mark on the essay. However, feedback does not take the place of final grades. I don't see why one must replace the other.

Comment: Another incisive and on the mark column, Margaret Wente.  Clearly, your excursion to the frozen north did not give you the brain freeze with which some of your ultra-politically correct colleagues suffer.

Comment: ..."It's rad," a friend assured me. "It's a punk bar, but it's like super friendly. And they got cheap PBR." I was down. So I met them around 9:30 pm, pedaling to the place on track bike I bought off an Alpenrose racer. The directions were vague in the best sort of way. "Just look for a door," the friend told me. I pedaled down the street, looking for that door the way you look for treasure. Eventually, I found it. At the time, I didn't know I'd be opening that door on a near weekly basis for the next two years. But the best bars are like that. You don't plan on being a regular. You just become one. The Know became my home in a way that Portland became my home. Anyhow, that first night we stayed until close, buying round after round of PBR. We talked about dreams and hopes and decisions and goals and books and bikes and beers and girls. We found love at The Know...

Comment: In order to critically examine Canada's health care system, the general Canadian public needs to first disabuse itself of two fallacies; 
1. Canada's health care is free; and
2. Canada's health care is among the best in the first World.

In fact, neither is true. One critic of Canada's health care system has stated to the effect: Canada has a Chevrolet system at Cadillac prices. 

Like many Canadians, I've paid at least tens of thousands (perhaps hundreds of thousands) of dollars in taxes during my life time toward health care expenditures, and probably used less than $5,000 worth of  medical services. This being said, I'm in favour of universal, public health care (especially for children and the elderly), believing that the overall health of the society is a general good. Still, it's time to look more critically at what should and shouldn't be covered. Otherwise, health care spending will consume ever larger portions of tax dollars, at the expense of other public needs in Canada.

Comment: The kirpan (Sikh Dagger or Sword)) is a religious symbol, however, it its never used as a weapon. Nevertheless, the religious requirement that baptized Sikhs wear the kirpan has caused problems for believers in many areas, especially where the custom clashes with local ordinances against carrying weapons. 

In 2006 the Supreme Court of Canada ruled  that a Quebec  school board had violated Gurbaj Singh Multani’s religious freedom, and he won the right to wear the kirpan in school provided it was concealed and secured.   

Former BQ Leader, Gilles Duceppe, just argued on CTV’s Question Period, that Multani and other Sikhs are not allowed to take the kirpan on board an airplane.  Public safety and security  extends to other practicalities -  the integrity of public services with photo ID (Transit Cards, Medical Service Cards, Drivers’ Licence) used to access government services, and the safety of  employees who handle cash and other valuables under the watchful eye of CCTV.

Comment: One of the primary problems with the current ‘reform’ is the validity of the evaluation systems. If you or the paper or whoever is claiming that such selection is backed by valid longitudinal data showing significant improvement for a majority of students then such statements as yours are meaningful.  If that data does not exist then such statements are at best questionable if not wishful nonsense.
I am aware of data that shows a teacher can have a positive outcome longitude educational outcomes but I am not aware of data that shows the selection process is effective in selecting teachers who have positive outcomes across a range of educational objectives.
An attempt to improve selection data by increasing testing has proved to be counterproductive. There were good reasons to doubt the original premises six years ago of accountability and choice but the only data I have seen is that they are expensive but ineffective.

None of them would have done so if they hadn't found a way around the stairway problem. 

Heck, my niece lives in a half-million dollar home that has a ladder to a loft that pre-dates current code. She would like to upgrade the ladder but isn't allowed to unless she converts it to a stairway, which just won't fit. There's nothing remotely slum-like about her home with a loft.

We probably agree that our building codes need to be upgraded and enforced. However, allowing people to use ladders to access sleeping quarters is where we may have to agree to disagree.

A United Europe is in everyone's interest.

Comment: This article garnered headline news in the City Region section. The printed version reads: "SAT scores lower in math, writing". 
The article goes on to identify that math and writing scores were three points lower. The scores are on a 200-800 scale. 
It is impossible to know how important the three point drop is unless one knows how much the scores tend to vary. But it is a pretty safe bet that a three point drop is not statistically significant. Yet the headline implies that the three-point drop is newsworthy. 
Instead the headline might have been about the higher scores among Oregon students, which run between 12 and 31 points higher. But that is good news.
Or, it could note the differences between low and high economic groups, which is serious. Those differences run more than 100 points.

Why are those economic based differences so great? It's either advantages, harder work or both. If it is not advantage, do we believe the low income are just not working hard enough?

Comment: Thanks to the Globe and Mail for this.  This is a really, REALLY important story.

I've never been in uniform, so I became aware through--among other movies-- an  Oliver Stone feature made back in the early 1990s.  Not, not the big hits, "Platoon." and "Born on the fourth of July."  I'm talking about the 3rd and hugely unsuccessful last film of the trilogy: Heaven and Earth, starring Tommy Lee Jones.  Remember that?  No?  You're not alone.  Cost $33 million to make.  Box office: $6 million.  Big, fat flop.  Because it was just...too...hard to take. Jones plays a post-war vet who's suffering from what we would soon call PTSD.  And how.  

This is so tragic, especially as Rifleman Desmond bared his soul to the Veterans Appeal and Review Board.  

So: we've heard a lot in recent days about a Ministry of Defence $62 billion increase in the odds of much more of the same. Just this week: looks like 4,000 more chances for U.S. troops in the same blighted country.  God help them all.

Comment: I suppose she could have held teleconferences or video conferences while traveling. Although that seems unlikely given that she was vacationing with her family. If she didn't hold any sort of meetings at all, I would say it was fraudulent. On the other hand, requiring legislators to turn in actual expenses supported by receipts, would create a significant accounting burden. It would probably be a full time job for someone to monitor and verify expenses and receipts. I think a better solution would be to only allow per diem when they are traveling away from their home district. That doesn't mean paying per diem to legislators from the Valley that come to Anchorage for meetings. Many of us commute and can't claim those expenses on our taxes or get reimbursed. It certainly appears that many take advantage of a system that has been set up without much thought to actual costs or what is realistic for per diems.

Comment: Without re-hashing the merits (there are some) and deficiencies AL, the fundamental problem with this doc is that it emerged from a dreadful institution: the ‘synod of bishops’, a creation of Paul VI (arguably the most autocratic pope in the modern age). Paul actually proposed language for Lum.Gent. that the pope was‘accountable to the Lord alone’—fortunately the Theol.Commission cut it out.

Bishops are bishops in their own right (the fact that today most of them are essentially appointed by the pope is a problem that needs to be addressed). Comment: Canada doesn't have much of a horse in the combat aircraft race. Building our own would be a tremendous cost - well in excess of what even the F-35 is going to be. However, there are a lot of areas where Bombardier (and Viking) aircraft would be a good fit. The CP-140 fleet needs replaced, and the 737-based P-8 is the prime contender - a similarly sized and capable CS300-derived airframe would work well. The CS300 would also be an appropriate platform for an AEW&C aircraft a la the 737/Wedgetail Australia bought. The Global is an excellent SAR platform, as evidenced by the Raytheon Sentinel. New Guardian-400s from Viking would also be excellent replacements of the DHC-6s in the arctic. Support and transport missions are also possible - the C-130H tanker fleet needs a replacement, after all. A CSeries MRTT would be a very capable option. The list goes on.

Comment: Like Mr. Wuerthner, I've spent a lot of time and driven a lot of miles to observe the burns in the aftermath of big wildfires.

There are clearly instances where smart forest management slowed down forest fire and it's instructive for me as a practioner to view these scenes. But there are many more examples in the big, hot, weather driven blazes (the ones that create most of the smoke that irritates us) where unmanaged and managed forests stands were equally consumed.

What fascinates me, after working a lifetime in the western woods, is how these ecologically rich, economically valuable forests that survive now mostly on federal lands evolved without our help! Look mom, no management!

There's a good Forest Service read on pre-Euro Westside forest fires which agrees and disagrees with Mr. Wuerthner as, often,  do I:

 https://www.fs.fed.us/pnw/sciencef/scifi46.pdf

Comment: "No options, no futures, no margin buying, no leverage". You still are confused about what a multiplier is. You seem to be using the term applied to a financial ratio, specifically the debt-to equity ratio, sometimes called the equity multiplier in a very confused way. That is applied to the company and not the shareholders. You reference to "bulge banks' is even more instructive. You seem to think this is a bank run. Even more instructive is the trading range for "the last seven years." What happened 7 years ago? A seem to recall a big stock market crash? The way to measure volatility is the relevant share price to the stock market, called a beta. 1.0 is volatility matching the market, 1.20 means it's 20 percent more volatile. HE's beta is .44, much more like a bond price. HE has paid a quarterly 31 cent divided since 1999. Not like a bond, but more like a British Consol. And in checking the share price today I was shocked to see it seems to have leveled out to just above 3.

Comment: Good article.  Some clarifications, though:

The study saying there's more dioxin from landfills than incinerators is from an outfit at Columbia U. funded by the incinerator industry: See www.seas.columbia.edu/earth/wtert/newwtert/sponsors/ They publish "tobacco science," skewing facts to favor incineration. They compare total emissions between landfills and incinerators without adjusting for the amount of waste disposed (far more waste goes to landfills). Also, incinerator dioxin data is horribly underestimated in the U.S., by a factor of 30-50 times since they don't use continuous sampling, but only test for 6 hours a year on the facility's best behavior, without capturing data from when emissions are FAR higher during startup, shutdown and malfunction times.  Data on dioxin emissions from landfills are even more of a fiction, since the data is not collected, and it's basically all guesswork.

Comment: As it is now Paul, we have mediocre medical care.  Seeing how the system treats older people especially is eye opening.  Yeah, everything is fine until there is a problem even the slightest non-standard.  Months to schedule specialist consults, months to schedule tests.  It is an illusion that America has excellent health care.  The easy standard problems will be taken care of under pretty much any system.  The harder less common problems are not handled well now and treatment could only improve.  One example of possible radical change is computerization.  Symptoms are symptoms.  A lightly trained person could assist in gauging and interpreting symptoms and feed them together with standard blood tests results into advanced diagnostic computer programs.  The computers would order additional tests if diagnosis is uncertain.  We have the technology to computerize diagnosis now, but the medical industry stands in the way it would cost them money.

Comment: "But when we first read The Communist Manifesto or Capital, Marxism seemed like a great idea, too. In reality, of course, communism turned out to be a nightmare, providing neither equality nor freedom to its people."

MSW, this is a rather facile statement:  rhetorically it makes your point, but only because it appeals to the canard that Marxism=Soviet Communism.  As most scholars of the field (and not just leftist scholars) will tell you, you have to draw an clear distinction between the ideas of Marx himself and their later development:  one of which was Soviet style communism, but there are other schools of non-authoritarian Marxist thought.  When discussing Marx himself (e.g., the Manifesto or Capital) it is customary to refer to Marxian ideas--most of which were a critique of capitalism and almost none of which were about "communism", however defined.

Comment: Part 6
I would point out that there is a recent interpretation of one of the gospel texts based on a careful analysis of the Greek that suggests the Pharisees were once again trying to trap Jesus. At that time, there were two views among Jews about divorce: (1) a recent Pharisee view, that remains Jewish practice to this day, that a man can "for any reason" give his wife a "Git," a certificate of divorce, and thereby divorce her; and (2) an older practice based on Leviticus that either spouse can divorce the other in the event of sexual infidelity. And Jesus rejects the first when he said divorce was disallowed "for any reason,"  that is rejecting the Pharisee view. 

(BTW, Tridentinus, my Koine Greek is sufficient to test this interpretation again the text, and I am persuaded. What I cannot confirm on my own scholarship is whether the dispute among the Jews was indeed operative at that time, for that requires knowledge of the Talmud, and I don't have the wherewithal to go there.)

Comment: Correlation is not causation. One would assume a drug company would pay a doctor to oversee a clinical trial or enroll patients by looking at who are the most experienced ones ie. had the most patients (which means the most prescriptions). They would not be doing this sort of work in a market that had gone generic so those prescriptions would be branded.

So they look in a non-generic market for a doctor with lots of patients to enroll in their study and compensate them for their time. That would then show that 'drug company payments mirror brand name prescribing' not because the payment influences the prescribing but the prescribing is what allows the drug company to find the right patient population to complete the final trials to bring a drug to market.

Comment: Perhaps following somebody else's rules is easier than truly accepting and living the good news,  doing the latter brings a whole different set of "rules," but these require the ability to honestly see oneself and others through eyes very different from those most of us were trained to use.  Instead of fear of punishment, perhaps it's a different kind of fear: the fear of letting others down, or the fear of reaching ones deathbed, only to realize how many of our gifts we  left on the table, instead of giving to others...  

The good news is empowering, awesome, and profoundly simple.  It calls us to a childlike outlook and innocence.  It drives us to welcome each day for the potential the new day gives us to give others.  We may not always understand how this works, but I think we ALL understand the pure innocence and bubbling joy of childhood.  The good news offers that to us.  It's the letting go that is hard, for doing that takes a real leap of faith.

Comment: Pat Wendt - Power corrupts. Absolute power corrupts absolutely. That sort of absolute power attracts already corrupted people and those who are not corrupted run fast away from that ring of power. All we can hope for, for as long as this bus keeps the wheels on (and I am increasingly doubtful it will last much longer) is that someone who still has some modicum of morality or good sense will take the office.

I don't know that Gary Johnson fits that bill (he's seeking the office after all, which suggests some level of power-fed corruption), but I know that Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump do not. Tastes of absolute power have corrupted them absolutely already. We might hope that Johnson, not having had access to that kind of power, might still want to represent the people at the end of 4-8 years, but we must always remember that power corrupts even people who weren't corrupt before they came to power. Remember.

Comment: You need to remember that sexual assault is just assault, with the added element of sexual purpose. Assaults come in three, disputably four categories, depending on seriousness. At the lowest level is common assault, which is simply the use of force, or threat or attempt to use force, on an unconsenting other.  The next level has two branches; assault causing bodily harm, and assault with a weapon. Those are self-explanatory. The next level is aggravated assault, which can be simply described as assault causing serious bodily harm. Finally, there is attempted murder, which is an assault committed with intent to kill. 

Any of the first three can be sexual assault if the assault is committed for  a sexual purpose. Sexual assaults are not categorized by the seriousness of the sexual component but, like ordinary assaults, primarily by the seriousness of the injury caused. 

Very low level sexual assaults, like very low level common assaults, are usually not prosecuted.

Comment: I think we have to be honest when attempting to ascribe attitudes to the historical Jesus. The word "xenos" in Matthew 25:35 means "stranger," as Sister correctly translates. Jesus' own attitude toward foreigners, however, appears to have been more complex (cf. the encounter with the Syro-Phoenician woman in  Mark 7: "It is not right to take the food of the children and throw it to the dogs" and the encounter with the Samaritan woman in John 4). 
I think we have to accept the fact that we feel called to extend hospitality to foreigners by many values we hold dear as Christians and as Americans, but recourse to the historical Jesus is not as helpful as we might like it to be.

Comment: I do not think this is to be welcomed. Of course, child abuse is to be condemned and punished, but I am afraid the law is not God. How is it possible to prove anything when decades have passed, especially given the propensity of people to believe their own narratives? I cannot forget the scandals in America when primal therapy uncovered numerous cases of "abuse" by fathers on children. The hapless men lost everything in the chorus of condemnation based on the sincere but, as it turned out, incorrect evidence of their children, who had essentially been led to this belief by the way that the therapy was structured.  A similar thing happens when certain types of interrogation technique are used--an innocent accused is led into confession. 
The sad truth is that if children and their guardians do not come forward at the time of the abuse, some people will get away with it--but the innocent are not condemned either, which is the basis of the (imperfect) legal system.

Comment: It's not Trudeau that will be forcing action on climate change. It's the planet itself. This summer was the hottest on record around the world. Next summer will be worse. Comment: As I understand it, that's not of what most of the backlog consists. It is important to remember rape kits are merely one form of evidence and resources are limited. In cases where the perpetrator admits guilt, the time and cost of running them is unnecessary. In cases where other evidence exists and is sufficient to convict or get a plea, the kit need not necessarily be run. In cases where it is determined no rape occurred, or charges are dropped due to the victim recanting, there is no reason to run the kit. 

Again, going from memory, that's what most of the backlog is. It isn't primarily kits in active investigations where DNA will be key that aren't getting run. It's prioritizing them that leads to the backlog.

Comment: The National Popular Vote bill would take effect when enacted by states with a majority of the electoral votes—270 of 538.  
All of the presidential electors from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes in all 50 states (and DC)—thereby guaranteeing that candidate with an Electoral College majority.
					
The bill has passed 34 state legislative chambers in 23 rural, small, medium, large, red, blue, and purple states with 261 electoral votes. 
The bill has been enacted by 11 small, medium, and large jurisdictions with 165 electoral votes – 61% of the 270 necessary to go into effect.
					
http://www.NationalPopularVote.com

Comment: It is utterly inexplicable that the Legislature is rushing forward with a tax that the voters overwhelmingly defeated months ago. Oregon needs to make its tax system more progressive, not less, and this new tax is perhaps the most regressive there is, since there is no way to exempt essentials like food and medicine. Low and middle income Oregonians should not pay one cent more in price increases while millionaires pay almost the same income tax rate as someone making less than $20,000 per year.

And throwing in the towel on the corporate income tax makes no sense. Reform it, for heavens sake. Business would likely support reasonable reform.

Our lawmakers need to listen to the very reasonable proposal from the business community of a temporary tax increase to get past the current budget crisis, with future reform discussed when there time to find a solution that is fair to all.

Comment: FWIW ... ransomware doesn't always look like an email from a friend.  I had a client who got a very authentic looking email that looked like it was from FedEx, clicked on the attachment which was supposed to be an invoice or other such innocuous document, but was actually a self-extracting ZIP file that loaded the virus then deleted the original file.

The virus does not immediately make itself known, but it was working in the background encrypting all the files.   Once its done, it will DELETE all the non-encrypted files, and all you're left with are files you cannot use without getting the decryption key.  The encryption key is self-generated by the virus, and the only person who can create the decryption key is the person who created the ransomware.

Comment: The stories of these young women leaves me with admiration for their willingness to suffer for their vocations and for the Church, with anger for their situation and with sadness that so much energy has to be wasted on the fight for women's ordination in the Roman Catholic Church.  It is a struggle worth having--just ask the women in the Episcopal Church who went through similar struggles fifty years ago or the women who followed in their footsteps and benefited from their prophetic witness.  I am one of the latter.  Raised Roman Catholic, I finally realized that I did not want to spend my life being angry at being seen as "less" as a woman and at that decision point in 1977 I was barely aware that the call to ordained ministry was lurking in a corner of my heart and soul but I did know that the Roman Catholic church did not have a monopoly on the Holy Spirit, or the Gospel or the life of faith.  I pray for these brave faithful young women and hope that those who have ears, hear.

Comment: "quality is never really the issue"

Comment: Don't expect huge changes. I spend my winters on a sailboat in the Eastern Caribbean and most of what you talk about is familiar. I carry cash because the bank machines are unreliable. Most local shops and services do not take credit cards. I carry small packs of tissue because of a lack of toilet paper. Even in a large modern marina the internet can be down for 3 or 4 days. Food is an exception. A local restaurant is usually good, but make sure the meat is moist cooked since the cuts are usually tough. Forget steak, and go for chicken, pork, goat or fish. The ex English islands tend to overcook like our mothers did. The French islands are excellent, especially the creole food. Just remember, it is still a third world location and if you leave the resort, expect a little culture shock.

Comment: Paul your problem is not one of blasphemy, but a general understanding of American private property rights.  The Alaska Constitution either does, or does not, give Alaskans an ownership right to the natural resources of the State.  We are either an ownership State or we or not.   If we are an ownership state then Alaskans have an ownership interest in the value of our natural resources, the PFD is the distribution of that ownership right, and Alaskans are Free to allocate that economic value according to our own lights, to satisfy our needs and pleasures according to our own estimate of their priority.  There are obvious Perils, that we will stress whiskey rather than milk, television over education, but these are the Perils of Liberty with which Alaskans are prepared to live.
Our job Paul is to struggle to impart to the popular imagination the great insight into the nature of Freedom; Hawaiian vacations notwithstanding.

The whole article is thought provoking.  Here is what she said about a women's diaconate:  "Permanent diaconate is basically a ministry of service. It is a compliant ministry of service, where obedience is its hallmark. Our patriarchal system views service as essentially a woman's duty. As long as the current gender norms govern the church, female diaconate, if it ever happens, will only uphold a gendered ecclesiology in theology and praxis. What is needed is not the incorporation of women into the lowest strata of the hierarchy, but the transformation of the whole church into diakonia [service]."  

She also spoke about the way religious life is evolving.

Comment: Side note: CATO Institute has some studies on why immigration is important to the economic growth and future of the US. Several years ago, women started having fewer children. Those women are past child bearing age now and there is no way to go back and increase the birth rate. That deferral of child bearing is still keeping the birth rate down with a decreasing number of child bearing women having children young enough to increase the birth rate. There is a virtually unstoppable trend toward a lower birth rate, a higher proportion of aged in the population, and a smaller percentage of younger productive persons in a slow or non-growth or declining economy. We are heading to where Japan is and where much of Western Europe, and China are heading. What is offsetting this for the US is immigration. And even current levels of immigration will not offset the lowering birthrate with Trump's restrictions.

Comment: Modern fridges already use R600a (isobutane) and commercial refrigeration is starting to move towards R290 (propane).  What the article does not say is that these gases are HC (hydrocarbons) yes the very thing we are supposedly trying to reduce under the Paris accord.

R290 (propane) is highly flammable and it sinks as it is heavier than air.  Home a/c if it is going to use this, means adding a flammable gas which if leaking could pool in the basement.  This will mean that eqpt can not be retrofitted to use propane, but all new eqpt, likely a new furnace as well will be required to help reduce spark issues which could cause leaking propane to ignite.  So if you need a new a/c you will have to buy a new furnace.

For car based a/c systems, using propane could be disastrous during crashes.  A small fire could easily get gas to catch on fire, meaning many more fiery wrecks. R1234yf is starting to be phased in, but it is patented and very expensive.  

Bottom line everything will cost more

As the author pointed out, a bond investor might not be able to handle the volatility of equities in general. At least historically, and one can go back much further in time than this ~ 14 year study, an investment in these two areas has been much less volatile than the overall market's volatility (look at both best and worst years), has provided investors with much less risk of loss of capital (see both losing periods and largest decline) and got them back to a new high in the value of their portfolio in a far shorter period of time (see time to breakeven.)
This approach will not be for everyone. But for me at least, the odds of achieving above returns while at the same time taking below average risk over the long term (decades) are without doubt in my favour. And decidedly better than owning bonds.

Comment: We bought a Kia Soul electric a few months ago; I've long wanted a EV and now they're well within reach.  Perhaps it's a post-mid-life-crisis "toy", but it's the first car I've ever been interested in owning.  We love it - it's practical, useful, spacious and quiet (so cool).  Above all it has a much smaller ecological footprint than the gas-fuelled car it replaced, especially since Ontario is (thankfully) 61% nuclear and 24% hydro.  We still have the gas SUV for an occasional long-distance trip, but the vast majority of my travel (when I'm not cycling) is carpooling to work or puttering around town (we live in rural Ontario).  Every couple of days I plug it into the 120 V outlet in the garage for off-peak charging (we haven't got a Level 2 240 V charger, yet).  It will be interesting to see the effect of winter on the range.

EVs are not for everyone - it depends upon your vehicle criteria.  But I sure wouldn't go back!  Thanks for the help, taxpayers!

Comment: The TAPS pipe had to be built in Japan because Nippon was the only company with a machine that could roll 48-inch pipe. A large portion of the steel itself was recycled from junk yards, believe it or not.

As for Sean Spicer -- don't you remember Obama's first press secretary -- Robert Gibbs? Seriously, Spicer is very slightly better than Gibbs. At least he can tell a joke and appears to know where Washington DC is located on a map, which Gibbs wasn't able to do either. Spicer might improve ... though he probably won't be given a chance. Gibbs hung on for ... well, it felt like forever. As a former journalist, I winced every time I saw his deer-in-the-headlights impression. I actually felt sorry for the guy ... at the same time I wanted to take him by the shoulders and slap him around and demand he learn how to do his job.

Never happened.

Comment: What is often lost sight of in the Omar Khadr saga is what took place during the very long period following Khadr's capture and his final release from prison.

I would argue that complicity of Canada's Government in prolonging Khadr's Gitmo incarceration is what justifies the apology. 

As for the $10 million payout, it was clear that the courts would likely ultimately award him much more if the matter went to trial and the trial to judgment and that the added cost to Canada of such litigation and interest on the award in light of the delay caused by the litigation would have been substantial.  The prudent course was to settle in these circumstances.

Comment: I respect your right to that opinion and far be it from me as someone in the mainline camp to question it. None the less, I disagree. Having attended RC Mass long long ago, as a young person at an RC affiliated university, and now being a worshiper in a liturgical mainline church, the similarities are there but the theology is different. Take the Eucharist. If your congregants actually knew what they are supposed to believe, they would know that you hold that the perfect sacrifice of the cross is not once and done, but MUST be "re-presented" by a man with special "ontological" powers to act as a stand-in for Jesus. This is justified by the "Time-warp" argument that says time is meaningless to God.

We in the "high" church denominations certainly believe it is a sacrifice but one of praise and thanksgiving wherein we offer ourselves, our souls and bodies, imperfect as we are, to unite in the sacrament so that He may live in us and we in Him. He is present, but no do over of Calvary.
